intro: Dendrophthora mexicana, commonly known as the Mexican mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees in Mexico. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its woody stems and evergreen leaves. The plant lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while it provides some sugars through photosynthesis. It produces small, white or yellowish flowers and red berries that are dispersed by birds. Dendrophthora mexicana plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its native habitat, contributing to the biodiversity of forest ecosystems.
